values.description:
Sets the number of allowed wamv\_p3d sensors to 0. After merge, teams that include this sensor in their sensor\_config.yaml file will fail the compliance check.

To test:

1 . Verify that non-compliant configs are flagged as non-compliant:

```
cd ~/vrx_ws/src
hg clone ssh://hg@bitbucket.org/osrf/vrx-docker
cd vrx-docker
./prepare_team_wamv.bash example_team
```

Our example team should fail validation because our sensor\_config.yaml includes the p3d sensor.

2 . Verify that compliant configs pass.

* Edit example\_team/sensor\_config.yaml to remove the p3d sensor.
* Then run

```
rm  ~/.ros/log/latest/wamv_config-wamv_generator-1.log # see vrx-docker issue #16
./prepare_team_wamv.bash example_team
```

The output should tell you it’s now compliant.
values.title: prohibiting p3d sensor in compliance check

summary.raw:

To test:

The output should tell you it’s now compliant.
summary.html:
Sets the number of allowed wamv_p3d sensors to 0. After merge, teams that include this sensor in their sensor_config.yaml file will fail the compliance check.

To test:

1 . Verify that non-compliant configs are flagged as non-compliant:

cd ~/vrx_ws/src
hg clone ssh://hg@bitbucket.org/osrf/vrx-docker
cd vrx-docker
./prepare_team_wamv.bash example_team

Our example team should fail validation because our sensor_config.yaml includes the p3d sensor.

2 . Verify that compliant configs pass.

  • Edit example_team/sensor_config.yaml to remove the p3d sensor.
  • Then run
rm  ~/.ros/log/latest/wamv_config-wamv_generator-1.log # see vrx-docker issue #16
./prepare_team_wamv.bash example_team

The output should tell you it’s now compliant.

values.description:
Partially addresses issue #186 by disabling the color checker in our example dock worlds. This prevents teams from scoring points by reporting the default color sequence even when the light buoy is not present. The dock.xacro default value is also changed to false.

To test:

Launch an example dock task:

```
WORLD=dock0.world
roslaunch vrx_gazebo vrx.launch verbose:=true paused:=true wamv_locked:=true world:=${HOME}/vrx_ws/src/vrx/vrx_gazebo/worlds/$WORLD
```

Make sure you can’t contact the color checker service:

‌

```
rosservice call /vrx/scan_dock/color_sequence "red" "green" "blue" 
>>> ERROR: Service [/vrx/scan_dock/color_sequence] is not available.
```

Note that this should also work for all dockX.world files and all phase2\_dockX.world files, as well as the standalone launch file. To test the latter you have to rebuild the environment and use the launch file:

```
catkin_make
roslaunch vrx_gazebo dock.launch
```

‌
values.title: Dock disable color checker

To test:

Launch an example dock task:


Note that this should also work for all dockX.world files and all phase2\_dockX.world files, as well as the standalone launch file. To test the latter you have to rebuild the environment and use the launch file:

```

```

‌
summary.html:
Partially addresses issue #186 by disabling the color checker in our example dock worlds. This prevents teams from scoring points by reporting the default color sequence even when the light buoy is not present. The dock.xacro default value is also changed to false.

To test:

Launch an example dock task:

WORLD=dock0.world
roslaunch vrx_gazebo vrx.launch verbose:=true paused:=true wamv_locked:=true world:=${HOME}/vrx_ws/src/vrx/vrx_gazebo/worlds/$WORLD

Make sure you can’t contact the color checker service:

‌

rosservice call /vrx/scan_dock/color_sequence "red" "green" "blue" 
>>> ERROR: Service [/vrx/scan_dock/color_sequence] is not available.

Note that this should also work for all dockX.world files and all phase2_dockX.world files, as well as the standalone launch file. To test the latter you have to rebuild the environment and use the launch file:

catkin_make
roslaunch vrx_gazebo dock.launch

values.description:
Clarifying the navigation challenge scoring is under discussion.  This is an implementation of one of the options being discussed.  

To test

```
 WORLD=nav_challenge0b.world
 roslaunch vrx_gazebo vrx.launch verbose:=true       paused:=false       wamv_locked:=true       world:=${HOME}/vrx_ws/src/vrx/vrx_gazebo/worlds/${WORLD}
```

Number of gates = 3

Running time duration = 60

1. If USV doesn’t complete the course, score = 2\* \(60/3\)
2. If USV completes course, score = T/3, where T is elapsed time.

Note that the running score published is T/3.  If the running state times out, then the 2\*\(60/3\) score is set.

‌

‌
values.title: Modification to navigation challenge scoring

summary.raw:
Clarifying the navigation challenge scoring is under discussion.  This is an implementation of one of the options being discussed.  

To test

```
 WORLD=nav_challenge0b.world
 roslaunch vrx_gazebo vrx.launch verbose:=true       paused:=false       wamv_locked:=true       world:=${HOME}/vrx_ws/src/vrx/vrx_gazebo/worlds/${WORLD}
```

Number of gates = 3

Running time duration = 60

1. If USV doesn’t complete the course, score = 2\* \(60/3\)
2. If USV completes course, score = T/3, where T is elapsed time.

Note that the running score published is T/3.  If the running state times out, then the 2\*\(60/3\) score is set.

‌

‌
summary.html:
Clarifying the navigation challenge scoring is under discussion. This is an implementation of one of the options being discussed.

To test

 WORLD=nav_challenge0b.world
 roslaunch vrx_gazebo vrx.launch verbose:=true       paused:=false       wamv_locked:=true       world:=${HOME}/vrx_ws/src/vrx/vrx_gazebo/worlds/${WORLD}

Number of gates = 3

Running time duration = 60

  1. If USV doesn’t complete the course, score = 2* (60/3)
  2. If USV completes course, score = T/3, where T is elapsed time.

Note that the running score published is T/3. If the running state times out, then the 2*(60/3) score is set.

‌

‌

values.description:
See issue #188.

When fixed joints are involved, the URDF to SDF conversion removes the intermediate links. This is the problem reported in issue #188, as the reference links for the GPS and IMU doesn’t really exist in Gazebo. A workaround is to replace the fixed joint in URDF by a revolute joint with enough constraints to make it a fixed joint.

@{5b04a6cf8a69f52b3ba2e5db} , could you give it a try and let us know if this is enough to fix the issue?
values.title: Fix issue #188

summary.raw:
See issue #188.

When fixed joints are involved, the URDF to SDF conversion removes the intermediate links. This is the problem reported in issue #188, as the reference links for the GPS and IMU doesn’t really exist in Gazebo. A workaround is to replace the fixed joint in URDF by a revolute joint with enough constraints to make it a fixed joint.

@{5b04a6cf8a69f52b3ba2e5db} , could you give it a try and let us know if this is enough to fix the issue?
summary.html:
See issue #188.

When fixed joints are involved, the URDF to SDF conversion removes the intermediate links. This is the problem reported in issue #188, as the reference links for the GPS and IMU doesn’t really exist in Gazebo. A workaround is to replace the fixed joint in URDF by a revolute joint with enough constraints to make it a fixed joint.

@Kevin Allen , could you give it a try and let us know if this is enough to fix the issue?

values.description:
See issue #190.

The placards were not centered in the bays of the docks \(there was an offset in `X` and an offset in `Y`\).

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/1369147370-placard_uncentered.jpg)
All activation zones used in the dock score plugins are relative to the placards. This might be the reason of the inconsistencies reported while trying to dock in different bays. I didn’t find anything different on the `dock3.world` reported on issue #190 compared with `dock0.world` or `dock1.workd`  but hopefully these offsets were the underlying reason for the inconsistency.

This is the current state of the dock with the placards centered.

@{557058:6b6463b7-2835-47c7-8c22-fdef36e9e325} , could you give it a try and check if you get a more consistent behavior?

‌
values.title: Fix issue #190

The placards were not centered in the bays of the docks \(there was an offset in `X` and an offset in `Y`\).

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/1369147370-placard_uncentered.jpg)
All activation zones used in the dock score plugins are relative to the placards. This might be the reason of the inconsistencies reported while trying to dock in different bays. I didn’t find anything different on the `dock3.world` reported on issue #190 compared with `dock0.world` or `dock1.workd`  but hopefully these offsets were the underlying reason for the inconsistency.

This is the current state of the dock with the placards centered.

@{557058:6b6463b7-2835-47c7-8c22-fdef36e9e325} , could you give it a try and check if you get a more consistent behavior?

‌
summary.html:
See issue #190.

The placards were not centered in the bays of the docks (there was an offset in X and an offset in Y).

All activation zones used in the dock score plugins are relative to the placards. This might be the reason of the inconsistencies reported while trying to dock in different bays. I didn’t find anything different on the dock3.world reported on issue #190 compared with dock0.world or dock1.workd but hopefully these offsets were the underlying reason for the inconsistency.

This is the current state of the dock with the placards centered.

@Hashir Zahir , could you give it a try and check if you get a more consistent behavior?

‌

This should show up in any of the wayfinding or stationkeeping worlds.

values.description:
* Created new branch camera\_optical\_frame
* Update sensor model with sensor optical frame 
* Add name\_link\_optical  joint to match tf frame 
* Add joint that encodes transform between sensor and optical frame \*
* Modify sensor frame to add namespace. This ensures compatibility with localisation example

Usage:

```
roslaunch vrx_gazebo vrx.launch

roslaunch wamv_gazebo localization.launch

rviz
```

Add a camera visualisation to rviz.  Rviz should automatically add 3d objects to the camera visualisation using transforms and camera projection information.

This should resolve issue #140

Regards,

Jonathan.

‌
values.title: Camera optical frame

summary.raw:
* Created new branch camera\_optical\_frame
* Update sensor model with sensor optical frame 
* Add name\_link\_optical  joint to match tf frame 
* Add joint that encodes transform between sensor and optical frame \*
* Modify sensor frame to add namespace. This ensures compatibility with localisation example

Usage:

```
roslaunch vrx_gazebo vrx.launch

roslaunch wamv_gazebo localization.launch

rviz
```

Add a camera visualisation to rviz.  Rviz should automatically add 3d objects to the camera visualisation using transforms and camera projection information.

This should resolve issue #140

Regards,

Jonathan.

‌
summary.html:
• Created new branch camera_optical_frame
  • Update sensor model with sensor optical frame
  • Add name_link_optical joint to match tf frame
  • Add joint that encodes transform between sensor and optical frame *
  • Modify sensor frame to add namespace. This ensures compatibility with localisation example

Usage:

roslaunch vrx_gazebo vrx.launch

roslaunch wamv_gazebo localization.launch

rviz

Add a camera visualisation to rviz. Rviz should automatically add 3d objects to the camera visualisation using transforms and camera projection information.

This should resolve issue #140

Regards,

Jonathan.

‌

values.description:
Based on pull request #56.

Run each step in a separate terminal:

1. Run VRX: `roslaunch vrx_gazebo vrx.launch`
2. Set the pinger position and the Rviz visualizer: `roslaunch vrx_gazebo pinger.launch`
3. Run RViz - part 1: `roslaunch wamv_gazebo localization_example.launch`
4. Run RViz - part 2: `roslaunch wamv_gazebo rviz_vrx.launch`

In RViz, add the marker with topic `/wamv/sensors/pingers/pinger/marker/signal`. You should visualize a blue arrow like this:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/891894612-pinger_visualization.png)
‌

Here’s a complete tutorial:

[#!/osrf/vrx/wiki/tutorials/acoustic\_pingers](#!/osrf/vrx/wiki/tutorials/acoustic_pingers)

\(Feel free to edit it directly if you have suggestions\).
values.title: Acoustic pinger plugin

In RViz, add the marker with topic /wamv/sensors/pingers/pinger/marker/signal. You should visualize a blue arrow like this:

Here’s a complete tutorial:

(Feel free to edit it directly if you have suggestions).
